nodes.text: Cross-country differences in average per capita GDP growth (1960-1985) are determined by initial human capital, initial per capita GDP, investment, fertility, government policy, political stability, and price distortions

Data and empirical method: cross-section regressions for 98 countries (mostly 1960-1985), using measures from Summers and Heston, UN, World Bank and Banks; heteroskedasticity-consistent standard errors (White) and some weighted regressions
Main empirical claim: holding initial human-capital proxies constant, higher initial per capita GDP is significantly negatively related to subsequent per capita growth (conditional convergence)

Main empirical claim: higher initial human capital (proxied by 1960 secondary and primary school-enrollment rates) is significantly positively associated with subsequent per capita growth, conditional on initial GDP

Investment and fertility mechanisms: countries with higher initial human capital have higher ratios of physical investment to GDP and lower net fertility; investment positively correlates with growth and fertility negatively correlates with growth

Policy and institutional effects: higher government consumption share of GDP is negatively associated with private investment and growth, whereas measures of public investment show little robust positive relation with growth

Other adverse influences: greater political instability (revolutions, coups, assassinations) and larger deviations in investment-sector PPP prices (proxy for market distortions) are negatively related to investment and growth

Unexplained regional effects: even after controlling for measured variables, sub-Saharan African and Latin American country dummies remain significantly associated with lower growth, implying missing factors

Data details: human-capital proxies = school-enrollment rates (primary PRIM60, secondary SEC60), other variables include GDP60, GDP60 squared, investment ratios, government consumption ratio, fertility measures, PPP investment deflator deviations, political instability indices, continent dummies

Robustness checks: results persist using alternative dependent periods (1970-85), weighted regressions, subsamples excluding very low GDP, and instrumenting GDP60 with GDP70 to address measurement error

Quantitative result: coefficient on GDP60 (measured per $1,000 of 1980 US) is about -0.0075 implying a $1,000 higher initial GDP reduces annual per capita growth by about 0.75 percentage points when human-capital proxies are held constant

Mediation and residual correlations: school-enrollment effects on growth are partly mediated through higher investment and lower fertility; residuals from growth, investment, and fertility equations show patterns consistent with endogenous-growth and fertility theories (positive growth-investment residual correlation, negative growth-fertility residual correlation)

Measurement and proxy issues: enrollment rates may reflect flows rather than stocks of human capital, but tests using earlier (1950) and later (1970) enrollment data, student-teacher ratios, and literacy produce broadly consistent findings though data quality limits interpretation

Specific country examples: Pacific rim countries (Japan, Korea, Taiwan) had higher-than-typical enrollment for their GDP60 which raised predicted growth; many sub-Saharan African and some oil-exporting countries had enrollment shortfalls that reduced predicted growth
